section.title: Angina 1: ED Care
section.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts. All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction. Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Ischemic Heart Disease. Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section. The intent of this use case is to capture actions that commonly occur when a patient presents with unstable angina. Many of the steps in this use case occur concurrently in an emergent case. In similar scenarios, the same actions may occur in slightly different order. Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter. Hyperlinks are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case. Hyperlinks suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

formalpara.title: Patient
formalpara.para: A person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

formalpara.title: Provider
formalpara.para: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). All are skilled health-care professionals trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Registration Clerk (Reg. Clerk)
formalpara.para: A hospital employee that collects demographic, insurance and “reason for visit” information from a new patient and enters this information in to the Admission/Discharge/Transfer (ADT) system and/or the electronic health record (EHR).

formalpara.title: Triage Nurse (Triage RN)
formalpara.para: A licensed nurse that assesses symptoms, health-related complaints, and vital signs to determine the degree of urgency for care.

formalpara.title: Unit Clerk (UC)
formalpara.para: A hospital employee that performs administrative duties to facilitate workflow and patient care in the emergency department (ED) or a nursing unit.

formalpara.title: Emergency Department Technician (ED Tech)
formalpara.para: A hospital employee that is trained to provide basic tasks such as vital signs and laboratory draws under the supervision of an RN or Provider.

formalpara.title: Registered Nurse (RN)
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that is trained to provide nursing care to patients in inpatient and outpatient settings, within their defined scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Licensed Social Worker (LSW)
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that assists patients to improve their quality of life and social needs, and facilitates care after discharge.

formalpara.title: Nurse’s Aide/Assistant (NA)
formalpara.para: A trained healthcare worker that provides assistance with patient care, under the supervision of an RN.

formalpara.title: Clinical Pharmacist
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that often collaborates with physicians and other healthcare professionals to coordinate pharmaceutical interventions and promote health and disease prevention within their scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Dispensing Pharmacist
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare professional that dispenses medications, monitors medication parameters and potential drug interactions, and provides information about medications, within their scope of practice.

formalpara.title: Radiology Technician (Rad Tech)
formalpara.para: A licensed radiography professional that performs diagnostic imaging exams on patients to help physicians assess illness and injury.

formalpara.title: Radiologist
formalpara.para: A licensed physician that specializes in diagnosing and treating diseases and injuries by using medical imaging.

formalpara.title: EKG Technician (EKG Tech)
formalpara.para: A cardiology technologist that administers basic electrocardiogram tests to patients. The results are then read by a cardiologist or other licensed physician.

formalpara.title: Respiratory Therapist (RT)
formalpara.para: A licensed healthcare practitioner that provides care and treatment to patients requiring breathing and oxygenation support.

formalpara.title: Charge RN
formalpara.para: A registered nurse that is responsible for the efficient management of a nursing unit or department, including admissions, discharges, and the oversight of all nursing and support staff.

section.title: Description
section.para: 53 year old white male presents to the ED with chest pain and is diagnosed as having a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

listitem.para: Patient is brought to the ED by their family member
Patient is experiencing crushing chest pain (radiating to their jaw and neck), shortness of breath (dyspnea), nausea, and sweating (diaphoresis) after attempting to shovel their front walkway.
Patient has a history of stable angina that is usually relieved by rest, however the above symptoms worsened with rest.
Patient has taken one sublingual (SL) nitroglycerin (NTG) tablet, without relief.
Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical terminology.
EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.

row.entry: Patient’s family member (wife) pulls up to ED entrance, runs in to waiting area and calls for help.

entry.para: Patient’s family member, Patient, Triage RN, ED Tech
ED Tech and Triage RN run to the car (bringing a stretcher), assist patient on to stretcher and wheel the patient in to the Triage area.

row.entry: Triage RN completes a brief assessment to determine the patient’s condition and the urgency of required care.

entry.para: Patient, Triage RN, ED Tech, Family member
Chief Complaint: Crushing chest pain (8 out of 10), unrelieved by rest and 1 sub-lingual nitroglycerin (SL-NTG) tablet.

Current medications:
SL-NTG as needed. One taken 10 minutes ago.
Lovastatin 40 mg once daily – taken last night.
HCTZ 12.5 mg daily – taken this morning.
Lisinopril 10 mg daily – taken this morning.
High level assessment:
LOC: Alert and fully oriented
Temp: 99 F
BP: 169/98
HR: 106 and slightly irregular
Cardiac rhythm by ECG monitor: Sinus tachycardia (ST) with rare pre-mature ventricular contractions (PVCs)
Resp: 24 and shallow
Pulse Oximetry: 94% on room air
Skin: pale and diaphoretic

listitem.para: SNOMED-CT
LOINC

row.entry: Triage RN determines that patient has a severity index of ‘2’ requiring immediate emergency nursing care. Note: Steps 2 and 3 often occur concurrently.
Assessment of severity of condition. Is the patient’s condition life threatening?

entry.para: Triage RN, Patient, ED Charge RN, ED Physician, ED RN

step.para: Moves the patient via stretcher to the ‘Emergent’ section of the ED.
Notifies the ED charge nurse and ED attending physician of the new ED patient and their condition.
Flags the patient as requiring Emergent care by an RN in the EHR

listitem.para: Refer to Emergency Severity Index Triage Tool for EDs
Refer to Sidebar B Initial Evaluation of Ischemic Heart Disease/ VHA Clinical Guidelines

row.entry: ED RN initiates standing orders for emergency interventions that are indicated in the management of ischemic heart disease.

entry.para: Select and implement appropriate emergency interventions to stabilize ischemia.

procedure.title: ED RN does the following (unless noted as being delegated to the ED Tech):

step.para: Places the patient on a cardiac monitor (patient is still in ST with rare PVCs)
Obtains updated set of vital signs (BP: 158/90, HR: 102, RR: 22)
Places the patient on 2L of oxygen via nasal cannula (NC)
Evaluates chest pain (still 8 out of 10, crushing, radiating to jaw)

Obtains 12 lead electrocardiogram (ECG)
ST-elevation is noted on the ECG
ECG interpretation (by machine): Anterior wall MI
ED Provider is notified
Starts a peripheral intravenous (IV) line – performed by EDT
Sends blood sample for Chem 7, CBC, cardiac enzymes (troponin, CK, and CK-MB), Lipid profile, PT/PTT – orders for labs entered by RN, blood drawn and sent by EDT

Administers medications
325 mg chewable aspirin
Highlights the medication in the eMAR, scans the medication, next scans the patient, then administers the medication after receiving BCMA verification of appropriate administration
2 mg Morphine Sulfate IV
Follows process noted above for aspirin administration. Enters pain level of 8 out of 10 when prompted by BCMA system since administration of a pain medication requires documentation of the patient’s pain level.
1 tablet of .4 mg SL-NTG (Note: this is the second dose that the patient has received)
Follows process noted above for aspirin administration. Enters BP: 158/90, when prompted by BCMA system since administration of a SL-NTG should be held if SBP < 100.
Orders Chest X-ray (CXR)- PA and Lateral views
Note: Each of these interventions is ‘ordered’ by activating the “Standard ED Order Set for Chest Pain.” The ED RN enters the orders as verbal orders, which are then “signed off” by the Provider.

Note: RN specifies ‘Nurse draw’ when entering order for lab work. EHR integrates with department printer, which prints labels for blood tubes. If the RN had specified ‘Lab draw’ the blood draw would have been added to a Laboratory Technician’s work list.

entry.para: • Biomedical device integration to record VS and pulse oximetry
• Activation of standing order set for chest pain via CPOE by RN
• Documents medications that were administered in the Medication Administration Record (MAR)
• Refer to Standard ED Order Set for Chest Pain
• Refer to VA Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Ischemic Heart Disease
Provider receives notification that a verbal order has been placed in his/her name
Provider opens notification and views the task listed in their work queue
• Provider opens patient record in EHR and views data entered to date
• Provider enters ED room to assess patient (assessment results are documented in Step 13)
Registration clerk enters insurance and demographic information in to the EHR system via tablet as verified by the patient’s wife.
Registration Clerk enters the following information in to the system:
• Primary and Secondary Insurance information: Tricare, member #: xxx-xx, etc.
ED RN evaluates status of chest pain and vital signs

row.entry: Evaluate effectiveness of interventions and need for escalation of therapy.

entry.para: • Patient reports pain is a 5 out of 10
• VS: BP 150/90, HR 95, RR 20, Pulse Ox: 98% on 2LNC

• ED RN administers 1 tablet of .4 mg SL-NTG (Note: this is the third dose that the patient has received. Standing orders cover up to 3 administrations of SL-NTG. BCMA is used to record this administration.)
• Biomedical device integration to record VS and pulse oximetry
• Documents medications that were administered in the electronic Medication Administration Record (eMAR)
Radiology Technician (Rad Tech) receives notification that a diagnostic X-ray for an Emergent ED patient has been added to his/her work list
Management of work queue. Ensure the proper diagnostic test is performed on the proper patient.
Rad Tech receives notification that a task has been added to his/her work list for an Emergent ED patient.
• Rad Tech checks work list in EHR, completes the procedure as ordered and documents completion.
• Rad Tech flags the CXR as ‘ready for interpretation’ by Radiologist
Radiologist receives notification that a CXR is ready for interpretation for an Emergent ED patient.

row.entry: Accurate evaluation of CXR (taking reason for CXR and old films in to consideration)

entry.para: Radiologist receives notification that a chest film is ready for interpretation.
• Radiologist checks work list in EHR, views the indicated CXR and enters the CXR results and interpretation.
EHR integration with PACS and Notification system

row.entry: Provider receives notification that the CXR results are available.

entry.para: Provider receives notification that a CXR ordered in their name has been ‘resulted’.
• Provider pulls up results via hospital issued cellphone.
• Provider utilizes EHR to view chest film to compare against previous images (if available).
EHR integration with PACS and Notification system
Registration clerk (Reg. Clerk) obtains Advance Directive and Authorization for Disclosure of Personal Health Information (PHI) from patient.
Reg. Clerk provides tablet with Advance Directive and Authorization for Disclosure of PHI information of forms.
• Patient waives Authorization for Disclosure of PHI at this time.

row.entry: EHR integration with hand held tablets

entry.para: K: Authorization for Disclosure of Protected Health Information
ED RN receives notification that diagnostic results have been returned for this patient.
Ensure results are not life threatening or will not affect indicated treatment. Evaluate initial of cardiac enzymes for ischemic indications.
ED RN receives alert that lab and CXR results have been returned. He/she accesses lab results in the EHR. Relevant lab values include:
• CXR: Normal. No mediastinal widening, valve disease, or CHF
• Visualization of lab and diagnostic reports

row.entry: Expedite History and Physical. Formulate differential diagnosis (i.e. Acute Coronary Syndrome vs. STEMI). Determine if patient is a candidate for emergency reperfusion.

entry.para: • Confirms past medical history (PMH) and enters active conditions to the Problem List (Stable Angina, HTN, Dyslipidemia)

• Confirms current medications:
Lovastatin 40 mg once daily – taken last night
HCTZ 12.5 mg daily – taken this morning
Lisinopril 10 mg daily – taken this morning

• Completes physical assessment
Neuro: Alert and fully oriented
CV: Chest pressure 5 out of 10 after 3 SL-NTG tablets, S1S2, No murmurs or gallop
Resp: 20 and slightly shallow. Lungs clear
GI: Abdomen soft, flat with bowel sounds in all quadrants
GU: Verbalizes no problems with voiding
Skin: Slightly pale. Diaphoretic. Warm and intact
Psych: Calm and cooperative with wife present
• Data entry to Problem List, Allergies and Current Medication
• Visualization of lab and diagnostic reports
M. Head to Toe Physical Assessment Components
Provider discusses clinical findings and treatment options with patient.
Engage and educate patient. Assess patient understanding to facilitate informed decisions.
• New diagnosis confirmed by ECG: Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction

listitem.para: This diagnosis is added to the Problem List

entry.para: • Since chest pain started 45 minutes ago, it is too early to see any elevation in cardiac enzymes (Troponin, CK-MB)

• Recommend emergent revascularization of coronary artery with cardiac catheterization and possible balloon inflation and/or stent placement based on clinical studies showing the best outcomes for this scenario. A referral to an Interventional Cardiologist can be placed immediately.
Alternative treatment is intravenous thrombolytic therapy
Pros and cons of each treatment discussed with patient
Provider can access Clinical Care Guidelines, American Cardiology Recommendations, and Risk Evaluation Following a MI resources via hyperlink or Infobutton, as needed
• Continued chest pain after administration of 3 SL-NTG tablets and elevated blood pressure indicate need for intravenous nitroglycerin (IV NTG)
• Beta-blocker medication is indicated for ischemic heart disease
Patient conveys their Goal, in relation to their new diagnosis

row.entry: Patient states that they, “Want to do whatever is necessary to maintain optimal heart function so that they can live a full life. That includes having a catheter placed in my heart.”

entry.para: Patient conveys their treatment preference and agrees to a plan of care.

listitem.para: Signs verbal order that ED RN entered to activate ED standing orders for patients presenting with chest pain
Emergency consultation with Interventional Cardiologist – initiated by Provider

Probable emergent cardiac catheterization (if confirmed by Interventional Cardiologist)
Nothing to eat or drink in preparation for procedure
Start IV NTG to manage chest pain
Start Beta-blocker (Metoprolol)
Immediately
Immediately
Within one hour
Immediately
Immediately
Immediately

row.entry: Provider utilizes CPOE to enter orders for agreed upon care.

entry.para: Determine appropriate orders for this patient with continued chest pain and a potential pending PCI.

• Interventional Cardiology Consult STAT
Reason: Acute Anterior Wall MI. Evaluate for Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)
• NPO (Nothing by mouth) for possible cardiac catheterization with PCI
• IV NTG. Start at 10 mcg/min – increase by 10 mcg/min every 5 minutes until pain free or SBP < 100. Maximum dose 200 mcg/min.
• Metoprolol 5 mg IV x 3 doses, at 2 minute intervals if HR >50 and SBP > 100.
• Give Metoprolol 50 mg p.o. 15 minutes after last dose of IV Metroprolol

row.entry: Provider pages Interventional Cardiologist on call to notify of STAT consult for John Doe, PatientID 233433. Int. Cardiologist accepts consult and will come to the ED to evaluate the patient immediately.
ED RN receives notification of new order for PatientID 233433.

entry.para: ED RN receives notification that the provider has ordered IV NTG for the patient.
• Metoprolol 5 mg IV and IV NTG bag is obtained from the medication Pyxis. IV tubing obtained from the supply cart.
ED RN administers cardiac medications, as ordered.

row.entry: Evaluate chest pain and how BP has been affected by NTG. Safe administration of additional meds to reduce cardiac ischemia.

entry.para: • ED RN evaluates vital signs and chest pain
• BP: VS: BP 150/88, HR 90, RR 20, Pulse Ox: 98% on 2LNC
• Patient reports chest pain 4 out of 10, in chest only
• ED RN opens eMAR for the patient and views the IV NTG order
• Scans IV NTG bag and then patient’s wristband
• Enters BP 150/88 when prompted to evaluate patient’s BP.
• Enters ‘I’ for Infusing in eMAR and rate of 10 mcg/min
• Primes IV tubing, sets IV pump to infuse 10 mcg/min, and starts infusion
• ED RN views Metoprolol 5 mg IV (x 3 doses) order in eMAR
• Scans Metoprolol 5 mg IV ampule (ED RN receives pop up notification to check heart rate prior to administration of Metoprolol. If HR < 50 the medication should be held)
• Enters ‘G’ for Given in BCMA and HR 90
• (Note: ED RN would go on to administer remaining IV and PO doses of Metoprolol as ordered, if well tolerated by patient)
• Biomedical device integration to record VS and pulse oximetry
Interventional Cardiologist arrives in ED and enters PatientID in to EHR.
Form differential diagnosis from information gathered. Identify additional questions or clarifications that need to be answered.

row.entry: Interventional Cardiologist views PMH, current medication list, allergies, chief complaint, diagnosis, provider and nursing notes, and diagnostic results (including labs, ECG, and CXR).
Interventional Cardiologist enters patient room to evaluate for emergent catheterization.
Diagnose patient. Determine eligibility for reperfusion therapy. Assess patient understanding of the recommended intervention to obtain informed consent.

entry.para: • Assesses patient, reviews health history and new diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.
• Evaluates for contraindications of reperfusion therapy
• Confirms recommendation of immediate cardiac catheterization with possible intervention
• Confirms that the patient has only had a small glass of water earlier that morning to take meds. Last solid food was the evening before.
• Explains the procedure, along with risks and benefits.
Patient provides consent for procedure recommended by the Int. Cardiologist.

Patient signs informed consent for Percutaneous Angiogram, Diagnostic Cardiac Catheterization, and possible Percutaneous Coronary Intervention with possible balloon angioplasty and possible stent placement.
Determine indicated pre-cath orders for this patient.
• Diagnosis: Acute Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction
• Ensure consent for procedure is on chart

• Start new IV line in left arm
Infuse 0.9% Sodium Chloride at 100 cc/hr

• Pre-op medications:
Diphenhydramine 50 mg IV ON CALL
Valium 5 mg PO ON CALL
ED RN provides transition of care report to the Cath Lab RN that will be caring for the patient.

row.entry: Report is completed verbally, over the phone. Cath Lab RN enters PatientID in computer, views all documentation entered in ED, along with Pre-Catheterization orders.

entry.para: Patient is transferred to ‘Holding’ area of Cath Lab via stretcher.
ED RN, Patient, Cath Lab RN
Cath Lab RN assumes care of the patient and will complete Pre-Catheterization orders while procedure room is being prepped.
Patient’s family member (wife) pulls up to ED entrance, runs in to waiting area and calls for help.
ED Tech and Triage RN run to the car (bringing a stretcher), assist patient on to stretcher and wheel the patient in to the Triage area.
Triage RN completes a brief assessment to determine the patient’s condition and the urgency of required care.
Chief Complaint: Crushing chest pain (8 out of 10), unrelieved by rest and 1 sub-lingual nitroglycerin (SL-NTG) tablet.

Current medications:
SL-NTG as needed. One taken 10 minutes ago.
Lovastatin 40 mg once daily – taken last night.
HCTZ 12.5 mg daily – taken this morning.
Lisinopril 10 mg daily – taken this morning.
High level assessment:
LOC: Alert and fully oriented
Temp: 99 F
BP: 169/98
HR: 106 and slightly irregular
Cardiac rhythm by ECG monitor: Sinus tachycardia (ST) with rare pre-mature ventricular contractions (PVCs)
Resp: 24 and shallow
Pulse Oximetry: 94% on room air
Skin: pale and diaphoretic

listitem.para: SNOMED-CT
LOINC
Sample Triage Assessment Form

entry.para: Cognitive Goal: Rapid assessment of patient condition.

row.entry: Triage RN determines that patient has a severity index of ‘2’ requiring immediate emergency nursing care. Note: Steps 2 and 3 often occur concurrently.

listitem.para: Moves the patient via stretcher to the ‘Emergent’ section of the ED.
Notifies the ED charge nurse and ED attending physician of the new ED patient and their condition.
Flags the patient as requiring Emergent care by an RN in the EHR
Flags the patient as requiring Emergent care by an RN in the EHR
Refer to Emergency Severity Index Triage Tool for EDs
Refer to Sidebar B Initial Evaluation of Ischemic Heart Disease/ VHA Clinical Guidelines

ED RN initiates standing orders for emergency interventions that are indicated in the management of ischemic heart disease.
ED RN does the following (unless noted as being delegated to the ED Tech):

listitem.para: Places the patient on a cardiac monitor (patient is still in ST with rare PVCs)
Obtains updated set of vital signs (BP: 158/90, HR: 102, RR: 22)
Places the patient on 2L of oxygen via nasal cannula (NC)
Evaluates chest pain (still 8 out of 10, crushing, radiating to jaw)

Obtains 12 lead electrocardiogram (ECG)
ST-elevation is noted on the ECG
ECG interpretation (by machine): Anterior wall MI
ED Provider is notified
Starts a peripheral intravenous (IV) line – performed by EDT
Sends blood sample for Chem 7, CBC, cardiac enzymes (troponin, CK, and CK-MB), Lipid profile, PT/PTT – orders for labs entered by RN, blood drawn and sent by EDT

Administers medications

2 mg Morphine Sulfate IV

1 tablet of .4 mg SL-NTG (Note: this is the second dose that the patient has received)

para.emphasis: Biomedical device integration to record VS and pulse oximetry
Activation of standing order set for chest pain via CPOE by RN
Documents medications that were administered in the Medication Administration Record (MAR)

listitem.para: SNOMED-CT
LOINC
RXNORM
Refer to Standard ED Order Set for Chest Pain
Refer to MAR Sample
Refer to VA Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Ischemic Heart Disease

section.title: Clinical Statements Required
section.para: Angina relieved by rest: here we need to describe the clinical statement needed to represent angina relief by rest (should it be a table, each clinical statement has its own section).

section.title: References for Clinical Management of Ischemic Heart Disease
DM 3: Referral for annual podiatry screening
Representing Negation for Patient with Coordination Issues
section.para: Issue raised by Sarita Keni on 8/22/17: Need to address how to show negation for a patient who has a lack of coordinaton. It was suggested that coordination may be codified, such as a value of 1-5.
